Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation2: A patient is recovering from a recent procedure and has slightly elevated vital signs.
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other, a silent reminder of the promise I made to help more at home. My partner’s voice echoes in my mind, gentle but tired: “Can you fold the laundry tonight? I’ve got dinner.” I nod, guilt already prickling at my skin, but my phone buzzes in my pocket. At work, Mrs. Carter just had her gallbladder out, and her chart shows a low-grade fever and a racing pulse. The nurse on duty is swamped, and I know I’m expected to check her vitals again, record them, and alert the team if anything changes. My hands hover over the laundry, but my mind is already at the hospital, picturing Mrs. Carter’s pale face. I feel split in two—one half pulled by the warmth of home and the other by the urgent responsibility at work. Both places need me, both expect me to show up, and I can’t shake the ache of letting someone down, no matter which way I turn.
